name: Reconstructed Attic
Late Classical Attic
Early Koine
pronunciations.desc: This is the pronunciation at the end of the Attic period and the beginning of the Koine period. Compared to earlier Attic, it had lost the pronunciation of the long diphthongs. It preserves aspirates and gemination.

contextSensitive.desc: before a voiceless consonant or a vowel
before/after consonant, or at the beginning of a word

name: Lucian - Samosatene
Lucian
pronunciations.desc: This variant of the Lucian pronunciation is intended to represent a roughly 2nd century A.D. pronunciation of greek. It notably preserves phonemic vowel and consonant length, takes the aspirates to their modern values, and leaves most vowels and diphthongs at various intermediate points.

name: Buthian
pronunciations.desc: This is the standard variant of the Buthian pronunciation. It evolves all letters to their modern values, except for οι, υ and η, which it leaves with late Koine values. The rough breathing remains pronounced. All vowel and consonant lengths are ignored. It reasonably represents the pronunciation of some Greek speakers in the 2nd century A.D., and the majority of Greek speakers in the Byzantine period. Note that speakers of Buthian frequently do not observe allophonic rules like voicing of σ before voiced consonants.

name: Modern
pronunciations.desc: This is the standard phonology of modern Greek. It merges most vowels and dipthongs with ι in a process called iotacism, it has no aspirates nor geminates, and it palatalizes several consonants.

name: Erasmian
pronunciations.desc: This is the pronunciation of classical Attic created by Erasmus. Erasmus did not have the IPA, so his descriptions were somewhat imprecise. This is a best effort transcription into the IPA. This pronunciation differs only slightly from the Classical Attic reconstruction. Erasmus reconstructs pitch accent and vowel length. Erasmus reconstructs the aspirates as fricatives. The name Erasmian is often used incorrectly to represent a pronunciation system that roughly follows the speakers native phonology. For an example of such a system, see the US Conventional system.

name: Polis Institute Erasmian
Erasmian
pronunciations.desc: This is a version of the Erasmian pronunciation modified to be easier for native English speakers to pronounce while still being more authentic and consistent than the US Conventional pronunciation. It eliminates geminates and uses a stress accent, like Buthian. This pronunciation claims to be accurate to the early Koine period.

name: US Conventional
Erasmian
pronunciations.desc: Many Seminaries in the US use a heavily modified version of Erasmian that avoids any sounds that are difficult for speakers of American English to produce. Additionally, English has many loanwords from Greek, meaning that English has its own pronunciation for certain words inherited from Greek. This system will often borrow those pronunciations back into the Greek pronunciation. This system is not coherent, and will vary wildly depending on the English accent of the speaker. The values given below are an attempt to give a rough idea of how this system works. This pronunciation evolves some aspirates to their modern values, but often deaspirates χ. It diphthongizes many monophthongs when US English would do the same. π, τ, χ, and κ are often aspirated at the start of words, as in English.

z and s are allophones in English, and thus in this pronunciation. The value used will often be the same one used in English.
